questions.question_text: A block of mass m1 rests on an incline of angle θ = 20°. The coefficients of static and kinetic friction are μs = 0.8 and μk = 0.5. It is connected via a massless string over a massless and frictionless pulley. Block m2 has mass 2 kg. If m1 = 1.6kg, what's the magnitude of the acceleration of the m2 (in m/s^2)?
questions.solution:
Solution guide (expanded, step-by-step):

We follow the same approach as in the image: compare forces to determine whether the system moves, then write the net force for the moving system including kinetic friction, derive the symbolic acceleration for the two-mass system, and finally substitute numeric values.

Step 1 — Define positive direction and identify forces symbolically
1. Choose the direction of motion to be positive: take downward for m2 (and therefore up the incline for m1).
2. List forces (symbolically):
   - On m2: gravity $m_2 g$ downward, tension $T$ upward.
   - On m1 (along the incline): component of gravity down the incline $m_1 g\sin\theta$, tension $T$ up the incline, normal force $N=m_1 g\cos\theta$, and (if moving) kinetic friction $f_k=\mu_k N=\mu_k m_1 g\cos\theta$ which opposes the motion.

Step 2 — Check whether the system will move (use static friction threshold)
1. The maximum static friction force magnitude is $f_{s,\max}=\mu_s m_1 g\cos\theta$. If m2 would pull m1 up the incline, the resisting forces that must be overcome are $m_1 g\sin\theta + f_{s,\max}$. The system will move (m2 down) if
   $$m_2 g > m_1 g\sin\theta + \mu_s m_1 g\cos\theta = m_1 g\bigl(\sin\theta + \mu_s\cos\theta\bigr).$$
2. Substitute the given values to check (use $g=9.81\ \mathrm{m/s^2}$):
   $$m_2 g = 2\times 9.81 = 19.62\ \mathrm{N}.$$
   $$m_1 g\bigl(\sin\theta + \mu_s\cos\theta\bigr) = 1.6\times 9.81\times\bigl(\sin20^\circ + 0.8\cos20^\circ\bigr).$$
   Numerically, $\sin20^\circ\approx0.34202$, $\cos20^\circ\approx0.93969$, so
   $$\sin20^\circ + 0.8\cos20^\circ \approx 0.34202 + 0.75175 = 1.09377,$$
   $$m_1 g(\sin\theta+\mu_s\cos\theta) \approx 1.6\times9.81\times1.09377 \approx 17.16\ \mathrm{N}.$$
3. Since $19.62\ \mathrm{N} > 17.16\ \mathrm{N}$, the static friction limit is exceeded and the system will move with m2 going downward and m1 moving up the incline. Therefore kinetic friction applies.

Step 3 — Write the net external force for the moving system (symbolic derivation)
1. Consider the entire two-mass system. External forces along the direction of motion (positive = m2 downward):
   - Driving force: $m_2 g$ (down on m2).
   - Resistive forces due to m1: gravitational component down the incline $m_1 g\sin\theta$ and kinetic friction $f_k=\mu_k m_1 g\cos\theta$. Both resist the motion of m2 downward because they act opposite the motion of m1 up the incline.
2. The net force accelerating the combined mass $m_1+m_2$ is therefore
   $$F_{\text{net}} = m_2 g - m_1 g\sin\theta - \mu_k m_1 g\cos\theta.$$
3. By Newton's second law for the combined system,
   $$ (m_1 + m_2) a = F_{\text{net}} = m_2 g - m_1 g\sin\theta - \mu_k m_1 g\cos\theta.$$ 
4. Solve symbolically for the acceleration $a$:
   $$\boxed{\;a = \dfrac{m_2 g - m_1 g\sin\theta - \mu_k m_1 g\cos\theta}{m_1 + m_2}\;}$$
   This is the general formula you would use for any given $m_1,m_2,\theta,\mu_k,g$ when the system moves with m2 downward.

Step 4 — Substitute the given numeric values and compute the acceleration
1. Plug in $m_1=1.6\ \mathrm{kg}$, $m_2=2.0\ \mathrm{kg}$, $\theta=20^\circ$, $\mu_k=0.5$, $g=9.81\ \mathrm{m/s^2}$:
   $$a = \dfrac{2.0(9.81) - 1.6(9.81)\sin20^\circ - 0.5\cdot1.6(9.81)\cos20^\circ}{1.6+2.0}.$$
2. Evaluate the components (to reasonable precision):
   - $m_2 g = 2.0\times9.81 = 19.62\ \mathrm{N}.$
   - $m_1 g\sin\theta = 1.6\times9.81\times\sin20^\circ \approx 1.6\times9.81\times0.34202 \approx 5.37\ \mathrm{N}.$
   - $\mu_k m_1 g\cos\theta = 0.5\times1.6\times9.81\times\cos20^\circ \approx 0.5\times1.6\times9.81\times0.93969 \approx 7.37\ \mathrm{N}.$
3. Numerator: $19.62 - 5.37 - 7.37 \approx 6.88\ \mathrm{N}.$ Denominator: $1.6+2.0 = 3.6\ \mathrm{kg}.$
4. Therefore
   $$a \approx \dfrac{6.88}{3.6} \approx 1.91\ \mathrm{m/s^2}.$$

Final answer: The magnitude of the acceleration of $m_2$ is approximately $\boxed{1.9\ \mathrm{m/s^2}}$ (downward for $m_2$).
